summary_points: 1. eBay's Q4 2024 revenue was $2.6 billion, a 1% increase year-over-year on both as-reported and FX-neutral bases, while full-year revenue reached $10.3 billion, a 2% increase year-over-year on both bases.
2.  eBay's Q4 2024 GAAP net income from continuing operations was $680 million, a 7% decrease year-over-year, compared to a non-GAAP net income increase of 8% to $607 million.
3.  eBay's Q1 2025 revenue guidance projects a 0% to 1% year-over-year FX-neutral growth, suggesting minimal to slight revenue growth compared to the same period in 2024.
1. Pool Corporation declared a quarterly cash dividend of $1.20 per share payable on March 26, 2025, to shareholders of record on March 12, 2025.
2. This 8-K filing, dated February 26, 2025, is a Regulation FD disclosure and includes financial statements and exhibits related to the dividend announcement.
3. No specific future impacts or risks were mentioned in this section of the filing beyond the declaration of the dividend itself.
1. Marriott International, Inc. issued $2 billion in notes (Series RR and SS) on February 26, 2025, with net proceeds of approximately $1.96 billion.
2.  The interest rate on the Series RR Notes is 5.100% and the Series SS Notes is 5.500%, both payable semi-annually, commencing October 15, 2025.

3. The Notes have optional redemption provisions allowing Marriott to redeem them, in whole or in part, at its option, and are subject to repurchase obligations in the event of certain changes in control, as described in the Prospectus Supplement dated February 24, 2025.
1. Agilent Technologies reported Q1 2025 revenue of $1.68 billion, a 1.4% increase year-over-year (YoY), with non-GAAP EPS up 2% YoY to $1.31.
2.  Full-year 2025 revenue is projected to be between $6.68 billion and $6.76 billion, representing 2.6% to 3.8% reported growth and 2.5% to 3.5% core growth.
3.  The Applied Markets Group (AMG) saw a 4% decrease in reported revenue and 2% decrease in core revenue YoY in Q1 2025.
1. SBA Communications Corp. exited the Philippines and is selling its Colombian assets, resulting in projected revenue losses of $115 million to $125 million from 2025 to 2028.

2.  The company's net income increased by $251.3 million year-over-year (2024 vs. 2023), primarily due to increased site leasing operating income and a $372.5 million benefit from revising tower asset lives.
3.  As of February 26, 2025, SBA has $204.7 million remaining under its stock repurchase plan.
1. Salesforce's fiscal year 2025 (ended January 31, 2025)  reported $37.9 billion in revenue, a 9% increase year-over-year.
2.  Operating cash flow for FY25 was $13.1 billion, a 28% year-over-year increase.
3.  Salesforce provides FY26 revenue guidance of $40.5 billion to $40.9 billion, representing a projected 7% to 8% year-over-year increase.
1. NRG Energy's 2024 net income of $1,125 million represents a significant turnaround from a $202 million loss in 2023.
2.  The company sold its Airtron business unit for $480 million, realizing a $204 million gain.
3.  As of February 26, 2025, NRG Energy has $1.5 billion remaining under its $3.7 billion share repurchase authorization.
1. Valero's net income attributable to stockholders decreased by $6.1 billion in 2024 compared to 2023.
2. Valero's total debt decreased by $1.06 billion in 2024, to $10.46 billion as of December 31, 2024.
3. Valero plans to contribute approximately $150 million to its pension and other postretirement benefit plans in 2025.
1. Altria's 2024 net earnings increased 38.5% year-over-year to $11.264 billion, driven by one-time gains, partially offset by lower operating income.
2.  The ITC's January 2025 ban on NJOY ACE imports and sales, currently under review, could materially harm Altria's business.
3. A $354 million impairment charge was recognized in Q2 2024, reducing the Skoal trademark's value.

1. Avery Dennison's 2024 net sales increased organically by 5%, driven by higher volume despite price reductions, but 2025 projections anticipate an unfavorable impact from foreign currency translation.
2.  The company incurred significant expenses in 2024, including $247.5 million in share repurchases, $13.1 million in restructuring charges, and a $75 million litigation settlement.
3.  Avery Dennison's fiscal year will change to a calendar year starting December 29, 2024, impacting future reporting.
1. Aflac's 2024 net earnings increased to $5.4 billion, up from $4.7 billion in 2023, while total revenues rose by 1.2% to $18.9 billion.
2. Aflac Japan's annualized premiums in force decreased by 3% year-over-year in 2024 due to limited-pay products reaching paid-up status.
3. Aflac recognized $2 million in interest income from nonaccrual loans in 2024, a new revenue stream.
1. Host Hotels & Resorts' 2024 revenue increased 7% year-over-year to $5,684 million, driven by acquisitions and group business, despite hurricane and wildfire impacts.
2.  The company anticipates a margin decline in 2025 despite projected RevPAR growth of 0.5% to 2.5%, due to increased operating costs.
3. Hurricane Helene caused $51 million in damage to The Don CeSar, delaying its reopening until late Q1 2025 and potentially impacting revenue.
1. Linde's 2024 operating profit increased by 8% ($611 million) compared to 2023, driven by higher pricing and productivity savings, despite flat sales.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, Linde had significant contingent liabilities totaling $1.7 billion related to terminated projects and contract disputes.
3.  Linde issued €2.2 billion in new notes in February 2025, while simultaneously repurchasing $600 million of existing notes.
1. Camden Property Trust established a $600,000,000 commercial paper program on February 25, 2025, to be used for general corporate purposes, including acquisitions and development.
2.  No commercial paper notes were outstanding under the program as of February 26, 2025.
3. The commercial paper notes have maturities of up to 397 days and will rank pari passu with other unsecured and unsubordinated indebtedness.

1. On February 26, 2025, Principal Financial Group announced its intent to exercise a put option to exchange $400,000,000 in pre-capitalized trust securities for U.S. Treasury securities, contingent upon a new securities issuance.
2.  The company plans to use the proceeds from this exchange to redeem $400,000,000 of its 3.400% Senior Notes maturing May 15, 2025.

3. The success of this plan hinges on the successful offering, sale, and settlement of a new issuance of pre-capitalized trust securities with a 2055 maturity; failure to complete this new issuance could prevent the company from executing its intended actions.

1. TJX Companies Inc. reported Q4 2025 consolidated comparable store sales up 5% and FY25 comparable store sales up 4%, exceeding their plan in both periods, driven entirely by increased customer transactions.
2.  For FY25, diluted earnings per share increased by 13% compared to the adjusted FY24 diluted earnings per share (excluding a $.10 benefit from an extra week in FY24).

3.  TJX anticipates a 2% to 3% increase in consolidated comparable store sales for FY26, but projects a decrease in the FY26 first-quarter pretax profit margin to 10.0% to 10.1% (down 1.0 to 1.1 percentage points from Q1 FY25), primarily due to lower planned incentive compensation accruals, the absence of a reserve release from Q1 FY25, and expected expense timing.
1. On February 19, 2025, D.R. Horton, Inc. issued $700 million in 5.500% Senior Notes due 2035 through an underwritten public offering, which closed on February 26, 2025.
2. The offering price of the notes was 99.314% of the principal amount, resulting in a purchase price of $695,198,000 plus accrued interest.

3.  The underwriting agreement includes extensive representations and warranties from D.R. Horton, Inc. and its subsidiaries regarding their financial condition, legal compliance, and business operations as of February 19, 2025.
1. Lowe's Q4 2024 diluted EPS increased by 12% year-over-year to $1.99,  partially driven by a one-time gain.
2. Lowe's projects a substantial increase in diluted EPS for fiscal year 2025, forecasting $12.15 to $12.40 compared to $9.91 in fiscal year 2024.
3. Lowe's 2025 outlook acknowledges continued uncertainty in the home improvement market.
1. Verisk Analytics sold its AER business in December 2024, resulting in a $12.1 million loss.
2. Accounts receivable increased by 30% year-over-year to $434.4 million in 2024, while outstanding senior notes increased by $200 million to $3,050 million.
3.  As of December 31, 2024, Verisk had $591.5 million remaining in its share repurchase program.
1. Verisk Analytics sold its AER business in December 2024, resulting in a $12.1 million loss.
2.  Accounts receivable increased significantly year-over-year by $100.2 million in 2024, reaching $434.4 million.
3. Verisk anticipates $392.4 million in future amortization expense for finite-lived intangible assets.
1. Verisk Analytics' 2024 revenue increased by 7.5% year-over-year to $2,881.7 million, driven by growth in underwriting and claims revenue.
2.  The company incurred a $12.1 million loss from the sale of its AER business in December 2024.
3. Accounts receivable increased by 30% year-over-year to $434.4 million in 2024.
1. Verisk Analytics, Inc. reported consolidated revenues of $2,882 million for the full year 2024, a 7.5% increase compared to 2023.
2.  For the fourth quarter of 2024, diluted adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations were $1.61, a 15.0% increase compared to the same period in 2023.
3. Verisk provides financial guidance for fiscal year 2025, projecting revenue between $3,030 million and $3,080 million and diluted adjusted EPS between $6.80 and $7.10.
1. Verisk Analytics, Inc. reported consolidated revenues of $2,882 million for the full year 2024, a 7.5% increase year-over-year (7.1% on an organic constant currency basis).
2.  Diluted adjusted EPS from continuing operations increased by 16.3% year-over-year to $6.64 for the full year 2024.
3. Verisk provided 2025 financial guidance, projecting revenue between $3,030 and $3,080 million and diluted adjusted EPS between $6.80 and $7.10, incorporating the impact of the AER divestiture.
1. Verisk Analytics, Inc. reported consolidated revenues of $2,882 million for the full year 2024, a 7.5% increase compared to 2023.
2.  Diluted adjusted EPS from continuing operations increased by 16.3% year-over-year in 2024, reaching $6.64.
3.  Verisk provides 2025 financial guidance, projecting revenue between $3,030 and $3,080 million, and diluted adjusted EPS between $6.80 and $7.10, though actual results may differ materially.

1. NRG Energy, Inc. reported GAAP Net Income of $1.1 billion for the full year 2024, a significant increase from a loss of $(202) million in 2023, primarily due to unrealized mark-to-market gains on economic hedges in 2024.
2.  As of February 20, 2025, NRG had completed $174 million of its planned $1.3 billion share repurchase for 2025.
3.  NRG has a Project Development Agreement with GE Vernova and Kiewit to develop up to 5.4 GW of new gas-fired generation, with the first projects expected to commence operations by the end of 2029.
1. NRG Energy, Inc. reported GAAP Net Income of $1.1 billion for the full year 2024, a significant increase compared to a $202 million loss in 2023.
2.  As of February 20, 2025, NRG had completed $174 million of its planned $1.3 billion share repurchase program for 2025.
3. NRG has a Project Development Agreement with GE Vernova and Kiewit to bring up to 5.4 GW of new gas-fired generation online between 2029 and 2032.
1. NRG Energy, Inc. reported GAAP Net Income of $1.1 billion for the full year 2024, a significant increase from a loss of $(202) million in 2023.
2.  As of February 20, 2025, NRG had executed $174 million of its planned $1.3 billion 2025 share repurchase program.
3. NRG has a Project Development Agreement with GE Vernova and Kiewit to develop up to 5.4 GW of new gas-fired generation, with the first projects expected to commence operations by the end of 2029.

1. 3M reiterated its 2025 guidance and provided an adjusted outlook for 2026 and 2027, projecting organic sales growth outperforming macroeconomic trends, an operating margin of approximately 25% by 2027, high-single-digit EPS growth annually, and over 100% free cash flow conversion.
2.  In 2024, 3M made net pre-tax cash payments of approximately $4.5 billion related to significant litigation costs and approximately $245 million in divestiture costs.
3.  3M plans to exit manufactured PFAS products by the end of 2025, with the associated impact on financial results presented as special items in its non-GAAP reporting.

1. 3M reiterated its 2025 guidance and provided a medium-term financial outlook at its 2025 Investor Day on February 26, 2025, projecting organic sales growth outpacing macroeconomic trends, an operating margin of approximately 25% by 2027, high-single-digit annual EPS growth, and over 100% free cash flow conversion.
2.  In 2024, 3M made net pre-tax cash payments of approximately $4.5 billion related to significant litigation costs, and approximately $245 million in divestiture costs.

3.  3M plans to exit manufactured PFAS products by the end of 2025;  the financial impact of this exit, including its effect on adjusted net sales and cash flow, is included in the company’s provided forward-looking non-GAAP measures.

1. 3M reiterated its 2025 guidance and provided a medium-term financial outlook for 2026 and 2027, projecting organic sales growth outperforming macroeconomic trends, an operating margin of approximately 25% by 2027, high-single digit EPS growth annually, and over 100% free cash flow conversion.

2.  In 2024, 3M made net pre-tax cash payments of approximately $4.5 billion related to significant litigation costs, and pre-tax cash payments of approximately $245 million associated with divestiture costs.

3.  3M plans to exit manufactured PFAS products by the end of 2025, and the impact of this exit on future financial results is considered to be too unpredictable to meaningfully reconcile with GAAP measures.
1. General Motors increased its share repurchase program by $6.3 billion on February 24, 2025, leaving $4.3 billion remaining.
2.  General Motors reduced its outstanding shares by approximately 110 million (10.4%) between December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2024.
3.  The company will increase its quarterly dividend by $0.03 per share starting in April 2025.
1. General Motors authorized a $6.3 billion share repurchase program on February 24, 2025.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, General Motors had fewer shares outstanding (under 1 billion) than its 2024 weighted average (1.055 billion).
3.  General Motors anticipates $4.3 billion in remaining share repurchase capacity after completing a $2 billion ASR program by June 30, 2025.
1. General Motors authorized a $6.3 billion increase to its share repurchase program on February 24, 2025, leaving $4.3 billion available after a $2 billion accelerated share repurchase agreement.
2.  GM's quarterly common stock dividend will increase by $0.03 per share starting April 2025.
3. The completion of a $2 billion accelerated share repurchase agreement is expected by June 30, 2025.
1. Dayforce, Inc. announced an efficiency plan on February 26, 2025, which includes a 5% reduction in its global workforce and is expected to be substantially completed by March 31, 2025.
2.  The plan is projected to generate approximately $65 million in pre-tax cost savings in fiscal year 2025 and $80 million on an annualized run-rate basis.

3. The company anticipates incurring total non-recurring restructuring charges of approximately $18 million to $21 million pre-tax for severance and related costs, plus $6 million to $8 million in non-cash charges for stock-based compensation, in the first quarter of 2025.
1. Dayforce, Inc. announced an efficiency plan on February 26, 2025, involving a 5% workforce reduction expected to be largely completed by March 31, 2025.
2.  The restructuring is predicted to generate approximately $65 million in pre-tax cost savings in fiscal year 2025 and $80 million on an annualized run-rate basis, as of February 26, 2025.

3. The company anticipates incurring $18 million to $21 million in pre-tax non-recurring restructuring charges and $6 million to $8 million in non-cash charges for stock-based compensation in the first quarter of 2025.
1. Dayforce, Inc. announced an efficiency plan on February 26, 2025,  including a 5% reduction in its global workforce, expected to be largely completed by March 31, 2025.
2. The plan is expected to generate approximately $65 million in pre-tax cost savings in fiscal year 2025 and $80 million annually thereafter.

3. The company anticipates incurring total pre-tax restructuring charges of approximately $18 million to $21 million in the first quarter of 2025, with additional non-cash charges for stock-based compensation estimated at $6 million to $8 million.
1. As of February 25, 2025, News Corporation had repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 25, 2025, 21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$640,873,825.22.
3. News Corporation's stock repurchase program, which aims to enhance shareholder value, is ongoing and subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 25, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.

2. On February 25, 2025,  21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased, at a highest price of US$30.69 and US$35.25 respectively, and a lowest price of US$14.88 and US$15.17 respectively.
3. News Corp's stock repurchase program intends to continue repurchasing shares from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 25, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 25, 2025,  21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased.
3.  The buyback program's completion date is not specified in this filing, and the ultimate number of shares repurchased will depend on market conditions and other factors.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 25, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 25, 2025,  21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased at prices ranging from US$14.88 to US$35.25.
3.  The company's stock repurchase program intends to continue repurchasing shares from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. Coterra Energy Inc. completed two significant acquisitions totaling $4 billion in January 2025, resulting in a projected 28% increase in their 2025 capital program.
2.  Coterra's net income decreased by $504 million year-over-year in 2024, reaching $1.1 billion.
3. A stockholder derivative lawsuit against Coterra remains under appeal as of February 3, 2025.
1. Coterra Energy Inc. significantly increased its long-term debt by $1.95 billion in 2024, reaching $3.535 billion by December 31, 2024.
2.  Net income fell by $504 million year-over-year (2024 vs 2023), primarily due to lower natural gas prices and production.
3. Coterra's 2025 capital expenditure program is projected to be between $2.1 billion and $2.4 billion, a 28% increase at the midpoint compared to 2024, primarily driven by recent acquisitions.
1. Coterra Energy Inc. completed $4.0 billion in acquisitions in January 2025, resulting in a 28% increase in their 2025 capital program to between $2.1 billion and $2.4 billion.
2. Despite a 4.1 MMBoe increase in production, Coterra's net income decreased by $504 million year-over-year to $1.1 billion in 2024.

3.  Coterra faces potential material adverse effects from future cybersecurity incidents and is currently dealing with a stockholder derivative lawsuit, *Fischer v. Dinges et. al.*, filed in June 2024.
1. Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc. settled a commercial arbitration award with Everly Health Solutions on February 24, 2025, agreeing to pay $595 million to resolve all claims.

2.  The settlement amount of $595 million is significantly lower than the original arbitration award of $988 million (including pre-award interest), but higher than the contractual damage cap of $79 million.
3. The settlement avoids further accrual of post-award interest and the costs and uncertainty of continued litigation.
1. Walgreens Boots Alliance settled a commercial arbitration award with Everly Health Solutions for $595 million on February 24, 2025,  avoiding further litigation costs and interest accrual.
2.  The settlement amount of $595 million is significantly less than the original arbitration award of $988 million but more than the contractually capped amount of $79 million.
3. The settlement agreement, while avoiding further legal costs and uncertainties, does not include any admission of wrongdoing or liability by Walgreens Boots Alliance.
1. Teradyne, Inc. announced a Financial Analyst Day to be held on March 11, 2025, at its headquarters.
2.  The filing is an 8-K report, indicating other events occurred on February 25, 2025.
3. The Financial Analyst Day will feature presentations on Teradyne's strategic imperatives, operating and growth strategy, and business outlook.
1. Williams Companies' net income decreased significantly year-over-year, falling from $3,179 million in 2023 to $2,222 million in 2024.
2.  In 2025, Williams anticipates fulfilling $4,132 million in performance obligations from customer contracts.
3. Transco received an adverse $110 million judgment in February 2025, although they have appealed and expect partial recovery.
